often hundreds of ways that you can say the same thing and hundreds of interpretations for one thing depending

that's enabling some clear dialogue between humans and computers one way

problem and that I mean take two to dialog tasks one of them question
answering and the other one chitchat one very popular question answering data set right now is Stanford squad data set
which takes a Wikipedia paragraph and a question as a pair and then it responds
with the indices of the answer to that question in the paragraph now people
really try hard to make models for this and to make it work but one problem is
that if you do make a model for this work very well it's not going to generalize to the chitchat task if you
try to talk to it it's going to just answer with indices and that's not really what we're looking for even
though they share the same core of contextual language understanding and this is something that pops up with more
than just this construed example that you really can't always get these tasks

really small subsets so that's kind of our our thought why why would we have a
dialogue research platform well if we bring all these tasks into one place and make it so that you have one agent and

natural language processing understanding and so we thought that having the
standardized method for training and data collection would would have more people come together and work on more

were trying to have a customer service bot but you were just working off of

this crowdsourcing internet marketplace for any task that a computer can't currently do so you're you as a
requester you will pay people to do bulk work that you wouldn't be able to do
because you're working on other things and then workers complete this work in the form of human intelligence tasks

if you're using a kind of vanilla Mechanical Turk you have a templated
workflow where you can select one of many standard tasks of like data data
collection labeling or surveys or any number of things and then you spin up a
bunch of hits from from that template workers work and complete the hit and
then you review that work and either accept or reject it one thing to keep in
mind though if you're rejecting the work you're refusing to pay for it so these are people the workers on the other side

way there's a way to either accept or reject directly in the workflow that

within a world as an if an agent is required to act it happens within the

agent receives that message so one thing that's really useful about having this
this paradigm where it's still within the world is that it's very easy to swap
out a Mechanical Turk agent for a pre-trained model which means once you've set up your your task for data
collection initially you can use the same task for testing your models and
seeing people's responses seeing how the workers feel they are doing or any sort
of model evaluation you might need the next and I feel this is actually one of
the most important elements of of this this framework is that it's not always
clear to really anyone how to say that a
workers ready for a task and the basic method for doing that right now is to
have qualification tests which are done externally to your task and are for the
most part a like a question/answer test and that does cover a lot of cases but
we wanted people to be able to handle rather complex conversations that don't
always make sense to have a test to do and might be very like one time specific
and we didn't feel like having workers complete or go out of their way to
complete a test would really make sense towards getting them to work on our
tasks so we instead decided that it's better to onboard the workers within the
task and we provide some in platform functionality for being able to do that
so our implementation is actually before the workers added to a wading pool we
can put them in an onboarding world and these onboarding worlds generally follow
one of two paradigms either it's just a set of turn-based steps where you're telling the worker what to expect and
having them respond to advance the conversation or you can have a mock of
the the real task with expected answers that you know are supposed to be correct in either case the the upsides of having
these onboarding worlds is that you're able to filter the workers from directly within the task and the idea here is
that instead of having a worker return multiple times and giving data that
isn't necessarily up to what you need you can have them filtered out after
just the first task the other thing that we're able to do is make sure that as
workers return they don't need to repeat the onboarding which can feel to workers like it's a waste of time especially if
they already know what they're doing so we can make it so that only the first time a worker tries out your tasks they
have to go through the steps of actually onboarding and this is a little graphic
of what the onboarding worlds do where a worker tries to answer with something invalid and then after answering with
the correct answer it says that it's putting them in the wading pool and then
the last kind of major engineering thing that we worked on was automated approval
of work the main problem here is that models can require a lot of data to
produce good results and collecting that data no matter how easy you make it to
bring together if that isn't up to to what you need if it isn't high-quality
data you might find yourself going through every single example again seeing if it's what you actually needed
and that can take even more time than it would the data in the first place so our
solution was to kind of push for automated approval of work and we did that with rule-based verification that
happens at the end of one of your data collection tasks and the idea is as you
finish collecting data if you have any sort of rule-based thing that you can establish whether it's something really
really simple like you're trying to do a machine translation thing and the responses aren't in the language that
you expect them to be that's something that you can easily rule out or a situation where you wanted your your
workers to talk about a specific animal and that animal doesn't come up once in the conversation like there are ways
that you can in certain cases validate these just rule-based but for more
complicated examples it becomes pretty difficult so while we support this paradigm we feel that it's generally
less effective to be filtering through the work than it is to try and ensure receiving good work in the first place
and there's more on actually working towards having good tasks later in the

ear your data or their experience it's going to talk about disconnects and how

regardless of the reason that this happens be it that they need to step away to do something different for a while or they their internet drops out

like it it's still not a good experience for for the person on the other end especially because again these are

and we kind of wanted to not have that be the case and so we really tried our
best to improve these these situations and the first one was we left the option to pay out to abandoned workers and we
think that this is actually a really important way to keep like workers trust
in you as a requester the idea here is that if they're in the middle of a task
and someone leaves they're still going to get paid for it because they were trying to do the work and even though
the work didn't get completed they completed their side of the task they were there and they were ready to have the conversation so we don't pay out to

tasks to set a maximum ACT time before a worker is like disconnected from an

considered disconnected we also made
some changes to support reconnecting so if you leave the page and come back but you're still within that act time you're

Mechanical Turk is a hard block where you essentially block the worker from
